title: Ticket #5504: condor_off -peaceful does not contact all requested machines
description:
CERN reports that

condor_off on a long list of hosts resulted in blackholing of remote commands

condor_off tells us it sent the command but the remote worker's MasterLog and StartLog show no sign of receiving the SIG.

With the list of hosts below:

b66657dc3a is the first machine which never received the remote command and all machines after it never received the command either. 

> [root@condorcm1 ~]# _condor_TOOL_DEBUG=D_FULLDEBUG,D_TOOL,D_NETWORK
> condor_off -debug -startd -peaceful b60bbafd29.cern.ch

remarks:
2016-Feb-08 11:15:54 by johnkn:
I notice that the output of condor_off claims to have sent the command to 52 of the 53 machines. The last one is missing from the output.

2016-Feb-08 11:39:52 by johnkn:
log has a message: 

   Can't find address for startd b6b03189be.cern.ch Perhaps you need to query another pool.

which explains why it never tries to send a message to the last machine at least.

2016-Feb-08 17:06:52 by johnkn:
So far my examination of the dbg log shows no failure messages and no difference in the pattern of condor_read and condor_write for successful vs. unsuccessful machines.

2016-Feb-09 16:01:02 by johnkn:
Further investigation shows that what is happening here is that condor_off is sending the "next off is peaceful" command to all but one of the startds listed on the command line. Then since it can't locate the last startd, it exits - without ever telling any master that it should shut down a startd.

As a fix for stable, I propose that condor_off should be keeping a list of unresolved startd's, and it should only talk to the master for those startds that it was able to send the "next off is peaceful" command.
